pros: They work with your schedule, very flexible and a great way to meet other students
cons: No cons that I can think of

review_title: Loved the job, toxic work environment
job_title: Associate Director of Undergraduate Nursing Recruitment in Detroit, MI
pros: Initially, you will be treated by a rock star! Once they have you, watch out! Loved the job and the campus.
cons: HR is almost non-existent, did not send exit survey (for a reason) after asking 4 times. Supervisor has her favorites, don't bother her with questions, she's "too busy". She will turn on you in a heartbeat and get rid of you if she doesn't like you . If she doesn't like you after your probation period, she will make your life a living hell until you quit.

pros: The students are generally kind, decent people, who are invested in their education.
cons: The campus claims to be part of its community, but it is gated. There's no life or culture on campus. It always feels depressing and dead. As a faculty member, I'd walk through the building where my office was and the vast majority of the faculty offices were empty or filled with junk, name placards gone, tiles are falling from ceilings, nothing works. A few programs and buildings are maintained - that's great. As they should be. Others are neglected. Enrollment is steadily declining. I don't suspect this institution to be here within the next 10-20 years. It's poorly managed, has bad work culture. The individual faculty and many workers are kind and thoughtful and brilliant. But taken as a whole, as a system, this place is a mess. I've never worked at an institution that seemed so desperate to attract students, to present itself as elite. Just about everyday, there are tours. Students and family members get funneled through buildings and given tours, but honestly, I feel like the university is misrepresenting itself and lowering its standards to accept more and more students who aren't prepared to go to college. Then, the institution doesn't support or invest in them properly. They just need the numbers to keep up appearances and keep the machine lubricated.

pros: Stable work environment. Nice vacation time
cons: Very low pay. No chances for advancement

job_title: Technical Support Specialist in Detroit, MI
pros: I gained experience in the field I am training into.
cons: Low pay. The university does not live up to it's mission.  There is a strong undercurrent of racism.  My supervisor was passive aggressive, and made unintelligent mistakes attributing them to underlings, with no consequences despite management being well aware.  Mediocre and boring atmosphere peppered with racism and religious hypocrisy.  People are very comfortable in their prejudices and assumptions. Two faced union atmosphere with right to work dismissals.  Many union workers doing absolutely nothing day to day but kept on the payroll.  People backstabbing one another right down to janitors and food service workers attempting to get one another fired. Biker looking people running departments, I could go on.

review_title: A great place to work, but budgets are tight and pay is low.
job_title: McNichols Campus Administration in Detroit, MI
pros:
Intelligent, friendly people to work with.
An organization not focused on profit, but on making the world a better place.
The mission is truly at the heart of the University, not just corporate blather.
Tuition remission (free education) is a great benefit.
Beautiful campus (McNichols Campus).
cons: Budgets are perpetually tight (at least in my years there), and staffs are therefore asked to do a lot.  But administrators understand this.  Although McNichols Campus is beautiful, the immediate area is not the nicest (Ferndale, a 10-minute drive, is a nice town, however).

review_title: Great place to work. Feeling of community on campus.
pros: Work-life balance was very good. times that I did work an occasional weekend for an event were not burdensome. It was a rewarding  place to work. Lots of opportunity for personal growth. Free tuition was really nice and gave me a perpective of life in the classroom for the students. Professors and academic deans work together as a cohesive unit. Office culture was very good. Offices across campus work together for the students. They truly want great things for the students.Very good benefits. Access to the dental school is a nig plus!
cons: Crime rate in the neighborhood around campus; however, campus itself is gated. I always felt safe on campus.

review_title: Good place to get tuition remission
pros: Working in Public Safety provided an easy job, with great salary and tuition remission available to yourself, spouse and children
cons: If employed with Public Safety expect to work bad shifts and every weekend. No trading days, or comp days. Upper management has very little police experience and it shows. Management is inflexible with scheduling and lacks leadership. Poor policing and teamwork.  Non existent work home life balance.  You will never be off midnights or afternoons and working all weekends

pros: Everyday was a new day.  I loved working with the students and seeing how much energy and life they had for higher learning.  The co-workers at the University of Detroit Mercy were great to work with.  Everyone was very friendly and helpful when I came on to work for this university.  I was always welcomed by the staff and people I worked with everyday.  The territories around the University of Detroit Mercy may not have been the greatest but there was always a strong interest is attaining a higher education, especially at the University of Detroit Mercy.
cons: Opportunity for advancement was not there.

pros: UDM was very flexible and catered to my schedule. The accounting department was very reliable and very organized and checks were mailed with little to know problem.
cons: There were not really any cons. I thought that the original paperwork was a little mundane in order to get the job rolling, but I think that I should have expected that given the nature of the work involved.

pros: Great balance between work and class schedule. I loved the people I worked with while I was there, they were amazing.
cons: No real complaints. The only struggle was occasional staffing. We had multiple part-time employees (all students) working in the office -- so, staffing capacity was not always ideal.

pros: Good for networking. It gives you a great experience at Division 1 level and in an urban atmosphere with a lot of diversity. Books and tuition paid for.
cons: Low stipend, can't live off of it. Unable to have a second job. Poor management. Unorganized/unsanitary working conditions.
